citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
*The nineteen year old whitetail deer is in need of veterinary evaluation. There is a one inch round area with an adjacent
1/2 inch round area of velvet missing on the tip of the left antler. The veterinarian has not been notified of the issue and no
current treatment has been started. The areas are dark red in color and bumpy in texture. In addition, the deer is slow to
rise from lying down but once up and moving around he moves freely.
*The seventeen year old sheep is limping slightly on/favoring the left rear leg when walking. The facility representative
states that the sheep had previously been on medication for arthritis but has been weaned off the medication.
*The llama is in need of shearing. The shearing has not been done yet this year due to repairs needed to the shearing
equipment. The long thick haircoat can potentially lead to overheating/heat stress.
Adequate and timely veterinary care is necessary to ensure the health and well-being of the animals.
The facility shall have the veterinarian examine the whitetail deer for an overall geriatric health evaluation and for the
lesions on the antler and the sheep for the limping issue. Correct by 7/13/23.
The facility shall shear the haircoat of the llama. Correct by 7/20/23.

The facility has completed a newly reconstructed record of animals on hand (old acquisition records destroyed in barn
fire). The acquisition information for the two kangaroos acquired since the fire do not contain the address or USDA license
number for the person/facility from whom the animals were obtained.
The information for one goat adopted out since the fire does not include the address for the facility to which the goat was
given.
Accurate and complete acquisition and disposition information is necessary for legal and medical tracing of the animals.
The facility shall ensure that they make, keep and maintain records that fully and correctly disclose all the required
information for all animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased or in their possession or which are
transported, sold, euthanized or otherwise disposed of.
Correct by 7/30/23.

The kangaroo enclosure has an approximately three foot x 9in section of insulation with plastic lining adhered to the
outside of one of the entrances to the shelter structure. The kangaroo have access to the exposed insulation. Chewing
on/ingesting the insulation can cause irritation and gastrointestinal upset. The housing facility for the kangaroos shall be
maintained in good repair to protect the kangaroos. Correct by 7/30/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
*The nineteen year old whitetail deer is in need of veterinary evaluation. There is a one inch round area with an adjacent 
1/2 inch round area of velvet missing on the tip of the left antler. The veterinarian has not been notified of the issue and no 
current treatment has been started. The areas are dark red in color and bumpy in texture. In addition, the deer is slow to 
rise from lying down but once up and moving around he moves freely.  
*The seventeen year old sheep is limping slightly on/favoring the left rear leg when walking. The facility representative 
states that the sheep had previously been on medication for arthritis but has been weaned off the medication.  
*The llama is in need of shearing. The shearing has not been done yet this year due to repairs needed to the shearing 
equipment. The long thick haircoat can potentially lead to overheating/heat stress.  
Adequate and timely veterinary care is necessary to ensure the health and well-being of the animals.  
The facility shall have the veterinarian examine the whitetail deer for an overall geriatric health evaluation and for the 
lesions on the antler and the sheep for the limping issue. Correct by 7/13/23.  
The facility shall shear the haircoat of the llama. Correct by 7/20/23. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility has completed a newly reconstructed record of animals on hand (old acquisition records destroyed in barn 
fire). The acquisition information for the two kangaroos acquired since the fire do not contain the address or USDA license 
number for the person/facility from whom the animals were obtained.  
The information for one goat adopted out since the fire does not include the address for the facility to which the goat was 
given.  
Accurate and complete acquisition and disposition information is necessary for legal and medical tracing of the animals.  
The facility shall ensure that they make, keep and maintain records that fully and correctly disclose all the required 
information for all animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased or in their possession or which are 
transported, sold, euthanized or otherwise disposed of.  
Correct by 7/30/23. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation.

The kangaroo enclosure has an approximately three foot x 9in section of insulation with plastic lining adhered to the 
outside of one of the entrances to the shelter structure. The kangaroo have access to the exposed insulation. Chewing 
on/ingesting the insulation can cause irritation and gastrointestinal upset. The housing facility for the kangaroos shall be 
maintained in good repair to protect the kangaroos. Correct by 7/30/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
